citation.article-title: Reclassification of Streptococcus pluton (White) in a new genus Melissococcus, as Melissococcus pluton nom. rev.; comb. nov.

p.s: Description of Melissococcus pluton nom. rev.
Melissococcus pluton (Pluton L.n. God of the lower world)

This description is based on the literature descriptions of 'Strep. pluton' (White 1912, 1920; Bailey 1963a,b, 1974; Bailey & Gibbs 1962; Glinski 1972a,b; Bailey & Collins 1982) and our own observations.
Colonies appear up to 1 mm in diameter.
Range in appearance from dense white or granular, entire, smooth and dome-shaped to relatively transparent umbonate or annular forms with clear centres and granular peripheries.
Greatest range of colony forms evident in isolates from A. cerana.
Cellular morphology:chains of lanceolate cocci (Fig. 1); cells often pleomorphic and rod-like forms may be present.
Gram positive; may destain easily.
Non-sporeforming, non-acid-fast, non-motile.
No growth in air; anaerobic to microaerophilic; no anaerobic growth without carbon dioxide; some strains inhibited by more than 5% (v/v) carbon dioxide.
Glucose and fructose usually only sugars to support growth; some strains dissimilate sucrose, melezitose and salicin.
Major amounts of lactic acid produced.
Small amounts of acetic, iso-butyric and succinic acids also produced.
Final pH 5.3.
Optimum growth temperature 35°C.
Growth between 20 and 45°C.
Optimum pH 6.5-6.6.
Requires a Na:K ratio of < 1.
Possesses Lancefield group D antigen.
Will not grow, or growth very feeble, on ordinary media.
Requires free cysteine or cystine additional to peptones or most yeast extracts.
The cell wall peptidoglycan type is lysinealanine.
Respiratory quinones are absent.
The long-chain fatty acid composition is primarily straight-chain, mono-unsaturated and cyclopropane ring acids.
The major fatty acids are hexadecanoic and lactobacillic acids.
The G + C content of DNA, determined by estimation of the melting point, is 29-30 mol % G + C.
Causative agent of European foulbrood of the honeybee.
Isolated from larvae of A. mellifera and A. cerana with European foulbrood.
The type strain is NCDO 2443.
